title: Paul Ernst (American writer)
text:
Paul Frederick Ernst (November 7, 1899 – September 21, 1985) was an American <a href="Pulp%20fiction%20%28genre%29">pulp fiction</a> <a href="writer">writer</a>. He is best known as the author of the original 24 "<a href="Avenger%20%28pulp-magazine%20character%29">Avenger</a>" novels, published by <a href="Street%20%26amp%3B%20Smith">Street & Smith</a> under the house name <a href="Kenneth%20Robeson">Kenneth Robeson</a>.
Biography.
Paul Ernst was born in <a href="Akron%2C%20Ohio">Akron, Ohio</a>. He "[took] up fiction writing in his early twenties". "A prolific manufacturer of potboilers-made-to-order," his stories appeared in a number of early Science fiction and fantasy magazines. His writing appeared in "<a href="Astounding%20Stories">Astounding Stories</a>", "<a href="Strange%20Tales">Strange Tales</a>" and "<a href="Amazing%20Stories">Amazing</a>", and he was the author of the <a href="Doctor%20Satan%20%28Pulp%20Character%29">Doctor Satan</a> series (8 stories in all) which ran in "<a href="Weird%20Tales">Weird Tales</a>" from 1935 to 1936. His most famous work was in writing the original 24 "The Avenger" stories in the eponymous pulp magazine between 1939 and 1942.
When <a href="pulp%20magazine">pulp magazine</a> work began to dry up, Ernst "was able to make a painless transition into the more prestigious "slick" magazines, where his word skill earned him higher financial rewards." As of 1971, he was "still active as a writer," including penning "Blackout" for the July 1971 issue of "<a href="Good%20Housekeeping">Good Housekeeping</a>" magazine. He died in Pinellas County, Florida in September of 1985, at age 85.
